column2: NORTH DAKOTA DMV PERMIT TEST
column4: North Dakota
column6: ND

column2: Question Text
column4: Answer1 Text
column6: Answer2 Text
column8: Answer3 Text

column2: 1. This road sign means:
column4: No U-Turn
column6: Do not enter
column8: Stop

column2: 2. To avoid crashes with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
column4: quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear, before changing lanes.
column6: sound your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
column8: adjust your rear-view mirrors every few minutes.

column2: 3. This road sign means:
column4: Lane ends
column6: Divided highway ends
column8: Two way Traffic

column2: 4. Tailgating:
column4: is a defensive driving tecnique.
column6: can frustrate other drivers and make them angry.
column8: helps reduce traffic congestion.
column10: cannot result in a traffic citation.

column2: 5. If involved in an accident, drivers should:
column4: avoid standing or walking in traffic lanes.
column6: stop their vehicle at or near the scene.
column8: turn off the ignitions of wrecked vehicles.

column2: 6. What is the first thing to do when you make a three-point turn?
column4: Turn left, go across the road so you come to a stop while you face the edge of the road.
column6: Signal with your right turn signal, then pull over to the right and stop.
column8: Signal with your left turn signal, then check carefully for traffic coming toward you.

column2: 7. What is the first thing you should do if your wheels move off the pavement?
column4: Ease your foot off the gas pedal and brake gently.
column6: Pull the steering wheel back.
column8: Pull over to the right and sound your horn to warn the other drivers.
column10: Try pumping the gas pedal to increase pressure.

column2: 8. You should use turn signals to indicate your intention with sufficient time to allow other drivers to see the signal:
column4: AFTER you move.
column6: BEFORE you move.
column8: even if they are short sighted.

column2: 9. If the traffic lights are out of service when you approach an intersection, you:
column4: must slow down and yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
column6: must come to a stop as you would for a stop sign.
column8: must continue according to the rules of right-of-way.

column2: 10. If another car has stopped in an adjacent lane in the same direction of travel, you should:
column4: pass the car on the left.
column6: be careful in case the other vehicle has stopped for a pedestrian.
column8: tap your horn to let the other driver know you are passing.
column10: speed up and pass the vehicle on the right.

column2: 11. You reach an intersection that is not controlled at the same time as a driver on your right, and both of you prepare to go straight. Who has the right-of-way?
column4: You.
column6: No one.
column8: Both.

column2: 12. At a light rail intersection, you should always:
column4: be alert and obey all traffic signals.
column6: look both ways before crossing the tracks.
column8: share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.

column2: 13. When a school bus is stopped with its red lights flashing:
column4: drivers may not pass while the red lights are flashing.
column6: drivers only need to stop if children are present.
column8: drivers don't need to stop unless they are in a school zone.

column2: 14. You must yield to other drivers:
column4: when they are driving a truck.
column6: when your traffic signal is a green.
column8: when it helps to prevent collisions.
column10: when the other drivers are on your left and you have reached an unmarked intersection at the same time.

column2: 15. When approaching any intersection or driveway, drivers should:
column4: drive at the fastest speed just before entering the intersection.
column6: pass other vehicles and then stop.
column8: look both ways and be ready to stop.

column2: 16. If traffic prevents you from crossing all the way across a set of railroad tracks:
column4: wait until the approaching train has come to a stop.
column6: wait until no trains are in sight.
column8: proceed only when there is room for your vehicle on the other side.
column10: proceed only when at least one-half of your vehicle can cross the tracks safely.

column2: 17. When you drive into the street from any driveway you:
column4: can disregard pedestrians if there is no sidewalk.
column6: must drive slowly so approaching vehicles and pedestrians can get out of your way.
column8: must stop and proceed only when there are no pedestrians or vehicles approaching.
column10: must honk the horn so approaching vehicles and pedestrians can allow you room.

column2: 18. If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
column4: proceed with caution until you see a train.
column6: go through when one of the tracks is free.
column8: go through as soon as the first train passes.
column10: wait until you have a clear view of both tracks.

column2: 19. On slippery roads, drivers should:
column4: increase their speed to avoid hydroplaning.
column6: slow down.
column8: not drive faster than 25 MPH.

column2: 20. As you approach an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. You should:
column4: be prepared to stop before the intersection.
column6: be prepared to stop in the middle of the intersection.
column8: speed up to beat the red light.
column10: apply the brakes sharply and come to a complete stop.

column2: 21. Alcohol:
column4: makes drivers more prone to take chances.
column6: makes it difficult for drivers to judge their condition.
column8: increases reaction time.

column2: 22. A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
column4: stop until the person is out of the crosswalk.
column6: speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
column8: slow down.
column10: sound your horn and proceed with caution.

column2: 23. ________ is the only effective way to reduce your Blood Alcohol Content (BAC).
column4: Time
column6: Drinking coffee
column8: Eating food

column2: 24. The most common cause of traffic crashes is:
column4: bad road conditions.
column6: wet pavement.
column8: human error.

column2: 25. A good rule for passing is:
column4: drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
column6: always remember to flash your lights and sound your horn to alert the other drivers that you are about to pass.
column8: try to get to the front of any line of slow moving traffic as soon as possible.
column10: pass on the right whenever possible.
